headline: Lawmakers call for the release of LIHEAP funds as health officials announce first cold-related death
summary: Maryland health officials recorded the state's first cold-related death of the season, a man in Frederick County, as federal LIHEAP heating assistance funds remain frozen. The Maryland Department of Health is urging residents in need to contact local health departments or call 2-1-1 to locate warming centers and shelters. The funding delay impacts approximately 100,000 households, including vulnerable seniors and veterans. Governor Moore temporarily covered November payments with $10.1 million in state funds, but future assistance remains uncertain without federal action. Health officials are advising residents to limit outdoor exposure and wear insulated clothing to prevent hypothermia and frostbite.

headline: On NC State’s campus, hundreds of students protest as fears of ICE persist
summary: Hundreds of NC State students marched on Hillsborough Street on November 21, 2025, to demand ICE and Border Patrol end their immigration crackdown in North Carolina, chanting "ICE out of NC now!" The protest erupted amid campus-wide anxiety over rumored ICE sightings and the federal "Operation Charlotte's Web," which has resulted in 370 arrests statewide. Mixed messages from law enforcement—Mecklenburg County Sheriff claiming the operation paused while DHS officials insisted it continues—heightened tensions. NC State administrators responded by advising faculty not to share student information with immigration enforcement and urging international students to carry status documentation. The state chapter of the American Association of University Professors condemned the crackdown as "racist and xenophobic," vowing continued support for affected communities.

headline: Waning immunity and falling vaccination rates fuel pertussis outbreaks
summary: A national pertussis outbreak is being driven by state policies that expanded nonmedical vaccine exemptions, including a Texas law allowing online exemption forms sent directly to schools rather than health departments, severely undermining surveillance. Fear of immigration enforcement further suppresses vaccination rates in Hispanic communities, while post-pandemic funding cuts have reduced public health outreach and slowed immunization registry reporting from daily to monthly. Despite CDC recommendations for maternal Tdap vaccination, only 60% of pregnant women receive it, leaving infants—who face the highest risk of hospitalization and death—increasingly vulnerable.

headline: Black Colorado leaders criticize DEI rollbacks prompted by Trump
summary: Black Colorado elected officials held a Capitol press conference condemning DEI rollbacks at the University of Denver and statewide, challenging Trump administration anti-diversity policies that threaten federal funding, while announcing forthcoming Black maternal health legislation and existing education standards as policy channels to address racial equity concerns and potentially preempt civil unrest.

headline: Tennessee Stands leader Humble ends state Senate campaign
summary: Gary Humble founded Tennessee Stands in 2020 to protest pandemic policies and galvanize resistance against COVID-19 emergency orders issued by state and local officials. The group has since evolved into a political force opposing Gov. Bill Lee's private-school voucher plan and backing candidates like Rep. Jody Barrett. Humble, who narrowly lost a 2022 primary challenge to Senate Majority Leader Jack Johnson, recently withdrew from his 2026 state Senate campaign, citing personal transitions and describing the political environment as "spiritually exhausting" with real costs on families.
